hadiths.english_translation: Chapter: What has been reported regarding performing Qiyam (night prayers) in Ramadan
Topics: Chapter heading for Qiyam Ramadan

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abd al-Rahman ibn Abd al-Qari: I went out with Umar ibn al-Khattab in Ramadan to the mosque, and behold, the people were scattered in groups, some praying alone and some praying in groups led by one reader. Umar said: By Allah, I think that if I gathered these people under one reader, it would be better. So he gathered them under Ubayy ibn Ka'b. Then I went out with him another night and the people were praying behind their reader, and Umar said: What an excellent innovation this is! And that sleep which you abandon is better than that which you are doing, meaning the last part of the night, and the people used to pray in the first part of the night.

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi al-Madani

narrators.name: Ibn Shihab al-Zuhri

potential_issues.issue: Ibn Shihab al-Zuhri classified as mudallis (Category 2) using 'an transmission

Topics: Incident of Umar ibn al-Khattab organizing collective Taraweeh
Unified Taraweeh led by Ubayy ibn Ka'b
Umar's statement approving organized Taraweeh prayer

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by al-Saib ibn Yazid: Umar ibn al-Khattab commanded Ubayy ibn Ka'b and Tamim al-Dari to lead the people in eleven rak'ahs. He said: The reader used to recite the lengthy chapters of the Quran so that we would lean upon staffs due to the length of standing, and we would not return except at dawn.

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi al-Madani

narrators.name: al-Saib ibn Yazid
narrators.full_name: al-Saib ibn Yazid ibn Akhnas al-Makhzumi

chainIssues: Muhammad ibn Yusuf has Saduq grade (lower than Thiqah)

potential_issues.issue: Mawquf hadith: Does not reach Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
potential_issues.impact: Stops at al-Saib ibn Yazid's report of Umar's command

potential_issues.issue: Muhammad ibn Yusuf has Saduq grade
potential_issues.impact: While Saduq narrators are generally accepted, this is the least reliable link in the chain. Does not significantly impact overall reliability as other narrators are of higher grades

potential_issues.issue: Unknown compiler at the beginning
potential_issues.impact: The initial reporter from the compiler is not identified

Topics: Umar's command to Ubayy ibn Ka'b and Tamim al-Dari to lead Taraweeh
Number of rak'ahs (eleven) for Taraweeh in Umar's era
Length of Quranic recitation during Taraweeh

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Yazid ibn Rumman: The people used to stand in prayer during the time of Umar ibn al-Khattab in Ramadan in twenty-three rak'ahs.

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi al-Madani

chainIssues: Short chain with few narrators between source and compiler

potential_issues.issue: Mawquf hadith: Does not reach Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
potential_issues.impact: Reports what occurred during Umar's era, not a Prophetic directive

potential_issues.issue: Variation in reported number of rak'ahs
potential_issues.impact: Hadith 7983 reports 11 rak'ahs while this hadith reports 23 rak'ahs, suggesting different practices or different times during Umar's reign

Topics: Number of rak'ahs for Taraweeh prayer (twenty-three)
Practice during Umar ibn al-Khattab's era

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by al-A'raj: I did not find the people except that they were cursing the disbelievers in Ramadan. He said: The reader used to recite Surah al-Baqarah in eight rak'ahs, so if he recited it in twelve rak'ahs, the people thought he had shortened the prayer.

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi al-Madani

potential_issues.issue: Mawquf hadith: Does not reach Prophet Muhammad ﷺ
potential_issues.impact: Report from al-A'raj about practices in his time

potential_issues.issue: First part about cursing disbelievers appears separate from Taraweeh discussion
potential_issues.impact: The hadith discusses a separate practice from the main focus on Taraweeh prayer mechanics

Topics: Practice of cursing disbelievers during Ramadan
Length of Surah al-Baqarah recitation in Taraweeh
Perception of shortening prayer when rak'ahs increased

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abdullah ibn Abi Bakr: I heard my father say: We used to leave (Taraweeh prayer) in Ramadan and hurry the servants with food fearing the coming of dawn.

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi al-Madani

potential_issues.impact: Reports a practice from Abu Bakr al-Siddiq's time without explicit Prophetic instruction

potential_issues.issue: Focus on practical concern rather than legal ruling
potential_issues.impact: The hadith illustrates timing concerns related to breaking the fast at dawn rather than prescriptive guidance on Taraweeh

Topics: Early departure from Taraweeh prayer in Ramadan
Concern about dawn approaching during Taraweeh
Servants hurried to serve food before dawn

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Urwah ibn al-Zubayr: Dhakowan, called Abu Amr, was a slave of Aisha, the wife of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ. She freed him with a deferred emancipation (dubur), and he used to stand (in prayer) and recite for her in Ramadan.

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi al-Madani

hadiths.english_translation: Chapter: What has been reported regarding night prayer (Qiyam al-Layl)
Topics: Chapter heading for night prayer

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Aisha: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: There is no person who intends to pray at night and is overcome by sleep, except Allah records the reward of his prayer and his sleep is charity for him.

narrators.name: Yahya
narrators.full_name: Yahya ibn Muhammad ibn Ahmad (one of Malik's transmitters)

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi al-Madani

chainIssues: Anonymous narrator (Unknown man) between Said ibn Jubayr and Aisha creates interruption

potential_issues.issue: Anonymous narrator between Said ibn Jubayr and Aisha
potential_issues.impact: The presence of an unknown and unidentified narrator (رَجُلٍ عِنْدَهُ رِضًا) breaks the chain continuity significantly. While he is described as having good character, his identity and reliability cannot be verified

potential_issues.issue: Multiple indirect transmission terms (عَنْ) in chain
potential_issues.impact: Though all narrators are reliable, the use of 'an throughout combined with the anonymous narrator affects chain strength

Topics: Reward for intending night prayer despite sleep
Sleep being charity when one intends night prayer

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Aisha: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: If any one of you becomes drowsy during prayer, let him lie down until sleep leaves him, for when one of you prays while drowsy, he does not know perhaps he will go to seek forgiveness and end up cursing himself.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Aslem (the father of Zaid): Umar ibn al-Khattab used to pray at night as much as he wished, and when it was the last part of the night, he would awaken his family for prayer, saying to them: Prayer! Prayer! Then he would recite this verse: And command your people to perform prayer and persevere in it. We do not ask you for sustenance; We provide for you. The good end belongs to the righteous (Quran 20:132).

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi al-Madani

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Said ibn al-Musayyab: Sleep before Isha prayer is disliked, and conversation (gathering) after it is disliked.

narrators.name: Malik

potential_issues.issue: Mursal transmission: 'It reached him' (بَلَغَهُ) - weakest transmission term
potential_issues.impact: This is a mursal hadith indicating indirect, unspecified transmission. While Malik and Said ibn al-Musayyab were contemporaries, the direct connection is not stated

potential_issues.issue: Missing direct transmission between Malik and Said
potential_issues.impact: The use of 'balaghani' instead of direct transmission terms like 'haddathana' or 'akhbarana' indicates an unspecified gap

potential_issues.issue: Unknown compiler at the top
potential_issues.impact: Initial reporter is not identified

Disliked practice of staying awake in conversation after Isha prayer

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abdullah ibn Umar: Night and day prayers are to be done in pairs (two rak'ahs each time), and if you fear the dawn approaching, pray one rak'ah to make it odd. Malik said: This is the established practice among us.

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi al-Madani

hadiths.english_translation: Chapter: The Night Prayer of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ for Witr
Topics: Chapter heading on Prophet's Witr prayer

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Aisha: The Messenger of Allah ﷺ used to pray eleven rak'ahs at night, and would make witr with one rak'ah. When he finished, he would lie down on his right side.

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abdullah ibn Umar: A man asked the Messenger of Allah ﷺ about night prayer. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ said: Night prayer is to be done in pairs, and when you fear dawn approaching, pray one rak'ah to make it odd for you.

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi al-Madani

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ibn Muhayriz: A man from Banu Kinanah called al-Mukhdarji heard a man in Syria called Abu Muhammad saying that Witr prayer is obligatory. Al-Mukhdarji went to Ubadah ibn al-Samit and asked him about this, and Ubadah said: That man is mistaken.

narrators.name: Malik
narrators.full_name: Malik ibn Anas ibn Malik ibn Abi Amir al-Asbahi al-Madani

narrators.name: Ubadah ibn al-Samit

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Aisha: Whoever fears he will sleep until morning, let him pray witr before sleeping, and whoever hopes to wake up in the last part of the night, let him delay his witr.

potential_issues.issue: Balaghani transmission - weakest transmission term
potential_issues.impact: Indicates indirect/unspecified transmission

potential_issues.issue: Mawquf at Aisha
potential_issues.impact: Companion's statement, not Prophetic

Fear of sleeping through witr
Hope to wake for late night worship

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Nafi': Abdullah ibn Umar would greet (make taslim) between every two rak'ahs and between the rak'ah in witr until he could attend to some of his needs.

chainIssues: Direct transmission from Nafi' to Ibn Umar

potential_issues.issue: Mawquf: Companion's practice (Ibn Umar)
potential_issues.impact: Reports Ibn Umar's specific practice

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abdullah ibn Dinar: Abdullah ibn Umar said: Maghrib prayer is the witr of daytime prayers. Malik said: Whoever performs witr early in the night then sleeps then wakes, if he wishes to pray, let him pray in pairs, which is what I have heard and what I prefer.

chainIssues: Includes Malik's juristic opinion appended to report

potential_issues.issue: Mawquf: Stops at Ibn Umar
potential_issues.impact: Companion's statement

potential_issues.issue: Hadith includes Malik's juristic opinion

Topics: Maghrib as witr of day prayers

Additional prayers after witr

hadiths.english_translation: Chapter: Witr Prayer After Fajr
Topics: Chapter heading on witr after fajr

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Said ibn Jubayr: Abdullah ibn Abbas slept then woke up and asked his servant: What did the people do? (He was blind at that time.) The servant went and then returned saying: They have finished (their prayer). He said: Did anyone pray before the dawn? The servant replied: Yes, only some people.

narrators.name: Abd al-Karim ibn Abi al-Mukhariqu
narrators.full_name: Abd al-Karim ibn Abi al-Mukhariqu al-Basri

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Qasim: I heard Abdullah ibn Amir ibn Rabi'ah saying: I pray witr while hearing the Iqamah or after Fajr (Abd al-Rahman doubted which one).

narrators.name: Abdullah ibn Amir ibn Rabi'ah

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abd al-Rahman ibn al-Qasim: I heard my father al-Qasim ibn Muhammad saying: I pray witr after Fajr. Malik said: Witr is only prayed after Fajr by one who slept through witr, and no one should intentionally delay their witr until after Fajr.

narrators.name: al-Qasim ibn Muhammad

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Hafsah (the wife of Prophet Muhammad ﷺ): When the muezzin finished the call to prayer for Fajr, the Messenger of Allah ﷺ used to pray two light rak'ahs before the established prayer.

potential_issues.issue: None major - all narrators reliable
potential_issues.impact: Strong chain

hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Abu Salamah ibn Abd al-Rahman: A group heard the Iqamah and stood to pray. The Messenger of Allah ﷺ came out to them and said: Two prayers at once? Two prayers at once? (expressing disapproval of praying the sunnah simultaneously with obligatory prayer time).
